iati-activity.title: Parliamentary Strengthening
iati-activity.description: The project aims to support the parliament in the four main areas of its constitutional responsibility: lawmaking, setting policy direction, executive oversight, and representation.

document-link.title: 00057935 Strengthening the System of Parliamentary Democracy in Georgia 2014-2016 EU
00057935 Strong Parliament in a Consolidated Democracy 20102013 NETH

iati-activity.title: Parliamentary Democracy System
iati-activity.description: Increased Functionality of the Parliament.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. Availability of Parliament's Institutional Reform Plan (IRP). 2. New mandate for the Parliament's international relations services. 3. Citizen-oriented public outreach activities. Number of Parliament's commitments in Open Government Partnership (OGP). 4. Number of amendments to parliamentary Rules of Procedure (RoP), including alignment with the latest constitutional changes. 5. Terms of Reference for donor coordination system in place and operational. 6. Number of committee action plans in place and operational. 7. Number of staff trainings on legislative and financial monitoring functions (summoning committee meetings, conducting government hearings, organizing public sessions, scrutinizing program budgets, utilizing budget execution and State Audit reports, etc.) 8. Action plan and communications roadmap of Committee on European integration in place and operational. Number of staff trainings on legal harmonization and overall integration issues; knowledge-sharing activities (study visits, conferences) with EU Member States. 9. Number of public outreach activities (Europe Day celebration, media workshops, etc.) on European integration processes.

baseline.comment: 1. The Parliament of Georgia lacks a vision of its development strategy. 2. Insufficient structured approach to international relations. Respective parliamentary services perform only protocol functions. 3. The Parliament's public trust is not sufficient. It lacks transparency and adequate public outreach. 4. Parliamentary Rules of Procedure (RoP) are not realigned with the latest constitutional amendments. 5. Donor coordination in the Parliament remains ineffective. 6. Parliamentary committees lack strategic approach to exercising their constitutional functions. 7. Law-making and oversight capacities of parliamentary committees remain weak. 8. There is a cross-party consensus in favour of Georgia's accelerated European integration; however, both Members and staff of the Parliament lack sufficient knowledge of European issues. 9. There is a low public awareness on Georgia-European Union relations, where the Parliament has a decisive role to play.

target.comment: 1. Institutional Reform Plan finalized and adopted by the Parliament. 2. Concept on International relations agreed with the Parliament; respective amendments to the parliamentary regulations made. 3. Communications strategy developed. Open Parliament Georgia Action Plan developed. 4. Amendments to Parliamentary Rules of Procedure (RoP) initiated 5. Newly introduced donor coordination mechanism operational. 6. All 4 strategic action plans of the committees are operational. 7. Parliamentary staff , including from targeted sector committees have greater capacities for fulfilling their duties 8. Action plan of the Committee on European Integration (CEI), communications roadmap and capacity development plan finalized. .

result.title: Objective
result.description: To secure long-term financial sustainability of the Georgian PA system

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Area of sustainably financed PAs

target.comment: At least 100,000 ha cat. I-II by 2013 400,000 ha cat. I-IV by 2017. This target was re-formulated following MTR as agreed by PEB.

actual.comment: 286,458.36 ha category I-IV

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Improved funding ratio of optimal needs of PAs measured by financial sustainability score card

baseline.comment:
0.47
The baseline level was 0.34 excluding the assumed increase in funding from revenues generated by the sister project (see below).

target.comment:
0.625
The ratio of current financing to optimally required financing reached 0.58 at year-end 2013 according to Financial Scorecard at mid-term review. This figure takes the total revenues available to PAs and divides it by the optimal funding calculation at 2013. Following MTR, the PEB agreed to adjust this target downwards from the original 0.7 for two reasons. First, the optimal funding foreseen in the Financial Scorecard increased compared to project outset, which made it even more challenging to achieve the planned financing level. A more fundamental reason to reduce the target, however, was that all assumed incremental funding sources are falling somewhat short of their planned additions to system revenues as described below. The Project Documents (Annex G) assumed an improvement of $1.114 million from the tourism and concession revenues generated as a result of the sister project. 2013 revenues from tourism and concessions amounted to almost $650,000. While not all tourism and concession revenues are actually attributable to the sister project, for purposes of these calculations they are all attributed to the sister project. Nevertheless, it seems unlikely that tourism revenues will increase by the planned amount by 2017. An improvement of $1.019 million was assumed from State funding. So far, while there has been a GEL increase in the budget, no dollar increase has been achieved (the GEL exchange rate weakened from $1.4/GEL in 2008 to $1.68/GEL in 2013). The 2008 baseline was $2.9 million in State funding for the PAs--the same amount as is shown in 2013. Finally, CNF's own target at present is to reach $800,000 per annum by 2017, an increase of $300,000 from 2013, but still $150,000 short of the planned $950,000 annual contribution assumed from CNF in the project document. If CNF funding can reach $800,000 and tourism revenues or the state budget can increase by $200,000, the revised 0.625 target can be achieved.

actual.comment:
A quantitative assessment of the funding ratio will be completed for the TE in 2017.
$612,000 disbursed by CNF in 2014, as such established annual target was factually reached.
During 2015, CNF plans to disburse $ 567,095. As of June 30, 2015, CNF factually disbursed up to $ 286,500, on track to meet the 2015 target. Expressed in Euro, CNFs main currency, CNF support to PAs increases annually, but due to the devaluation of the Euro against the $, the target for 2015 appears lower than planned.
Government funding in 2014 increased in GEL by 31.8% compared to 2013, due to major investments in infrastructure

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Critical ecosystems of protected areas providing habitats for endemic and endangered species are conserved

baseline.comment: Ecosytems are deteriorating

target.comment: Habitats in 4-5 Cat I-II PAs are conserved by 2013

actual.comment:
CNF currently supports 9 Cat I-IV PAs, including for better accountancy, planning, and patrolling.
Data collected for 4 species as part of the established pilot biodiversity monitoring program in BKNP during 2014 are being analyzed.
A replication biodiversity monitoring program is designed for implementation in Lagodekhi PA during 2015.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Ensuring sufficiency and predictability of revenue sources for the PA system

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Reduce annual funding gap by $440,000 by 2013

baseline.comment:
70% of basic funding
The baseline level in 2008 was actually 51%. 70% is the 2013 target with the sister project. The 2013 target is 88% including the projected increase in government funding. CNF was to add $440,000 to this increased 2013 financing level.
47% of optimal funding
See the comments above. This includes the projected revenues from the sister project.

target.comment:
94% of basic funding
Under the assumptions on the reduction of project targets discussed above (CNF adds $800,000 by project end and an additional $200,000 are provided by a combination of increased government and tourism related funding), following MTR the PEB adjusted this target is from 96% to 94% of basic funding (and 62.5% of optimal funding).

actual.comment:
Financial scorecard at MTR assessed combined support from government and donors to cover 86% of basic funding, or 58% of optimal funding.
In 2014, CNF reduced the funding gap with $612,000, for 2015 the projection is $ 567,095.
CNF is on target to the agreed annual reduction of $ 800,000 by project end (revised as agreed by the PEB following the MTR).

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: US$ value of capitalization of sinking fund.

actual.comment: Technically speaking, the value of the GEF Sinking Fund (SFAF1) is still $1,000,000, since no additional donations to this particular sinking fund were made. Meanwhile CNF has received significant donations outside the sinking fund. To give a sense of the reality of the project, CNF reports $4,554,000 (taking into account GEF funding plus 1/3 of Euro 12 million funding from BMZ plus private donations). We are therefore significantly above the target of $2,435,000. To December 2014 we spent $2 million in the PAs and plan a further $567,095 in 2015, reaching our spending target of $2,435,000. In addition to this funding we have received a further EUR 5 million into the endowment, putting us on target for a long term funding capacity of $800,000 pa.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Number of PAs financed from CNF

baseline.comment: CNF is currently not financing any PAs

target.comment: Four to five PAs financed by 2013

actual.comment: In 2015, 9 PAs are receiving support from CNF: 6 PAs receive full operational support (BKNP, LPA, VPA, TPA, MNP and JPA), while 3 PAs (Kazbegi, Kintrishi and Algeti) are receiving planning and infrastructure funding from KfW and "basic" operational support-- salaries top-up and some smaller items--from CNF.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Increase in tools PA system revenue generation

actual.comment: An agreement in principle has been reached with the MoENRP for the relevance of introducing PA entry fees. High level staff changes have hampered making further progress.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Long-term annual funding capacity of CNF available for Georgia based on its endowment, sinking fund and other regular annual commitments.

target.comment:
$950,000 (original target)
$800,000 (revised as agreed by the PEB following the MTR)

actual.comment:
CNF is on target to the agreed annual reduction of $ 800,000 by project end.
In 2014, CNF reduced the funding gap with $612,000, for 2015 the projection is $ 567,095.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Raising cost-effectiveness and capacities of PAs

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
Increase in cost-effectiveness of at least 10 PAs measured by financial score card (part II, component II);
The discussion at MTR indicate that the FSSC is not feasible at PAs level and cannot be used to assess the cost-efficiency of PAs. The MTR suggested that this indicator be replaced by the following: \\\"An accounting system is in place at APA and adopted that covers all PAs\\\"

baseline.comment:
0.08
Only a very basic accounting system exists.

target.comment:
0.33
A modern and fully functional accounting system is in place (original indicator)
An accounting system is in place at APA and covers all PAs (as revised by PEB after the MTR).

actual.comment: An accounting system (hardware and software) has been established at APA and covers all PAs. During the transitional year 2015, APA will upload balance sheet data.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description:
Adoption of site specific business plans at 10 PAs providing transparency on the optimum level of management costs
The MTR recommended that this indicator be replaced by the following: \\\"Technical assistance is in place for the preparation and the implementation of Operational Plans (OPs) by all the PAs covered by CNFâ€?

target.comment:
10 business plans adopted 10 PAs (original target)
Technical assistance has been provided and Operational Plans are in effect at all PAs covered by CNF (8-9 PAs) in 2016 (as revised by the PEB after the MTR).

actual.comment: Operational plans (OPs) were developed and submitted by BKNP, VPA and TPA. In 2015, additionally OPs were prepared for JPA, Kazbegi, Algeti and Kintrishi PAs.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Number of site managers trained in cost-effective management

target.comment:
At least three in a minimum of 10 targeted PAs (original target)
An accounting system for PAs is in place and is adopted by all PAs (target revised by the PEB after the MTR).

actual.comment:
Training in the use of the accounting system has been provided to 9 members of APA’s central staff and PA staff in 2014.
Additional training is planned for 2015 to staff of newly CNF-supported PAs.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Existence of electronic system to track changes in management effectiveness based on the METT score and - where appropriate - on the Financial Sustainability Scorecard.

baseline.comment: No such system exists

target.comment: Development and implementation of such a system

actual.comment:
In 2014, an updated METT Scorecard was prepared for LPA, in conjunction to a renewed grant agreement. For JPA the baseline METT Scorecard was prepared.
In 2015, updated METT Scorecards for renewed grant agreement will be prepared for TPA and VPA. Baseline METT Scorecards will be prepared for Kazbegi, Algeti and Kintrishi PAs.

result.title: Objective
result.description: To promote sustainable production and utilization of upgraded biomass fuels in heating applications in the municipal services sector of Georgia

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Installed capacity of incremental biomass heating systems, substituting fossil fuel-based heating, supported by the project

baseline.comment: Zero

target.comment: At least 2 MW

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Availability of long-term vision for bioenergy development in Georgia

baseline.comment: No long-term vision for bioenergy sector in Georgia

target.comment: National Bioenergy Strategy and Action Plan, which reflects broad stakeholder consensus, adopted by the Government of Georgia

actual.comment:
5%
Ministry of Environment and Natural Resources Protection of Georgia understands the necessity of strategic plan and is ready to facilitate the process.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Share of upgraded biomass fuels on the Georgian market that meet the national quality standards

baseline.comment: No standards

target.comment: Quality standards for upgraded biomass fuels and biomass heating systems are in place At least 30% of upgraded biomass fuels meeting the standards

actual.comment:
20%
Review of international standards of biomass fuels and equipment was conducted in the beginning of 2015.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Availability of detailed information on the amount and location of biomass in Georgia

baseline.comment: Biomass information scarce and unreliable

target.comment: Detailed inventory of available biomass resources with update mechanisms in place Established biomass monitoring system

actual.comment:
70%
Detailed inventory in Tbilisi area is done and for whole Georgia is in process of completion. Amount of biomass in Tbilisi is not sufficient for production. Amounts in regions appears to be enough for production.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Enhanced and approved policy and regulatory framework for efficient utilization of biomass energy

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Availability of long-term vision for bioenergy development in Georgia

baseline.comment: No long-term vision for bioenergy sector in Georgia

target.comment: National Bioenergy Strategy and Action Plan, which reflects broad stakeholder consensus, adopted by the Government of Georgia

actual.comment:
5%
Ministry of Environment and Natural Resources Protection of Georgia understands the necessity of strategic plan and is ready to facilitate the process.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Share of upgraded biomass fuels on the Georgian market that meet the national quality standards

baseline.comment: No standards

target.comment:
Quality standards for upgraded biomass fuels and biomass heating systems are in place
At least 30% of upgraded biomass fuels meeting the standards

actual.comment:
20%
Review of international standards of biomass fuels and equipment was conducted in the beginning of 2015.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Availability of detailed information on the amount and location of biomass in Georgia

baseline.comment: Biomass information scarce and unreliable

target.comment:
Detailed inventory of available biomass resources with update mechanisms in place
Established biomass monitoring system

actual.comment:
70%
Detailed inventory in Tbilisi area is done and for whole Georgia is in process of completion. Amount of biomass in Tbilisi is not sufficient for production. Amounts in regions appears to be enough for production.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Increased market confidence in the feasibility of production and utilization of upgraded biomass fuels

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Status of investors' decision to co-finance a biomass upgrading plant in Tbilisi

baseline.comment: Preliminary co-financing agreements made

target.comment: Investors closed financing as per pilot plant's business plan

actual.comment:
10%
Feasibility study was conducted for Tbilisi that revealed that it is not most appropriate location for investing . Thus, the Board decided to consider regional coverage and in this regards the competition that will help to identify production and utilization partners is now in process. Since Georgian Regions are considered as main target for the production and utilization, country wide business plan competition is in process of preparation. Competition will reveal partners.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Status of Tbilisi Municipality's decision to co-finance installation of 10 biomass boilers heating systems in municipal buildings

baseline.comment: Preliminary co-financing agreements made

target.comment: Tbilisi Municipality closed financing for the pilot boilers installation business plan

actual.comment: 10% according to feasibility study production and utilization is not feasible in Tbilisi under current setup. Regional municipalities will be considered as utilization partners. Locations to be identified once the competition is over.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Status of a dedicated funding window for bioenergy projects in Georgia

baseline.comment: No dedicated funding window available

target.comment: Dedicated funding window for bioenergy projects fully agreed with KfW (or other facility) and operational

actual.comment:
0%
N/A at this stage

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Created local supply of and demand for upgraded biomass fuels

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Status of Investment Grant Mechanism

baseline.comment: No mechanism

target.comment: Operational criteria agreed with relevant stakeholders and investment grants released

actual.comment:
0%
N/A at this stage

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Biomass upgrading plant in Tbilisi

baseline.comment: No biomass upgrading plant in Tbilisi

target.comment: Biomass upgrading plant in Tbilisi launched and operational

actual.comment:
0%
Feasibility study was conducted for Tbilisi that revealed that it is not most appropriate location for investing . Thus, the Board decided to consider regional coverage and in this regards the competition that will help to identify production and utilization partners is now in process.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Number of municipal buildings operating new biomass boilers using upgraded biomass fuels

baseline.comment: Zero

target.comment: At least 10 biomass boilers using biomass installed and in operation

actual.comment:
0%
N/A at this stage

result.title: Outcome 4
result.description: : Improved public knowledge and stakeholder capacities for bioenergy development and replication

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Status of Bioenergy Association of Georgia

baseline.comment: No formal vehicle for bioenergy stakeholder interaction

target.comment: Established Bioenergy Association of Georgia with a sustainable business plan which is able to continue operations after the project ends

actual.comment: 20% before bioenergy association is established, local NGO WEG created and will maintain biomass website ( repository for maintaining biomass related material and information) and support information distribution.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Number of new bioenergy projects initiated in Georgia

baseline.comment: No bioenergy projects, insufficient capacities

target.comment: At least 2 new bioenergy projects designed with financial closure and construction initiated

actual.comment: 20% country wide business plan competition is being initiated. Competition may reveal more than 1 interested partner.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1.1/ # of farmers received consultations and services of extension center 1.2/ # of innovations disseminated and applied by means of Extension Service provider. 1.3/ # of farmers trained in agri-business skills 1.4/ accessibility of green house for demonstration sessions and accessibility of seedlings for local farmers 1.5/ Accessibility of practical and theoretical knowledge, appropriate inventory and facility for local farmers 2.1/ availability of results of market survey 2.2/ availability of fruit dryer 2.3/ # of local farmers using fruit druer 2.4/ # of demonstration sessions provided at Gori University Dairy Plant. 3.1/ availability of market information on off season fresh products 3.2/ links established between fresh fruit buyers and famers 3.3/ availability of new cold storage facilities. 5.1/ # of inputs delivered and # of demonstration plots arranged 6.1/ # kindergarten building rehabilitated, renovated and operational 6.2/ # of water systems installed and operational 9.1/ Economic Baseline Survey conducted.

baseline.comment: 1.1/ No regular and institutionalized extension services accessible to all vulnerable communities; 1.2/ No facilities and formats for initiation of innovative methods in farming are available in the area. 1.3/ No agri-business training provided to farmers 1.4/No enough green houses operate in the region serving for demonstration needs and providing local farmers with seedlings 1.5/ No enough beekeeping farms operates and no trainings and education provided in this field in the region 2.1/ No high quality market information on dried fruits 2.2/No template design of simple fruit dryer available for farmers 2.3/ Lack of fruit drying facilities available for local farmers 2.4/ Lack of practical demonstration possibilities available for local farmers in processing 3.1/ Lack of market information on market for fresh off season products. 3.2/ No regular links between fresh fruit buyers and farmers. 3.4 / Lack of availability of cold storages. 5.1/ Lack of agriculture facilities and inputs in the area 6.1/ No modern and unsafe kindergarten existing 6.2/ No drinking water system existing in the selected area 9.1/ In 2014 UNHCR conducted “Participatory Assessment for Identification of Integration Needs of Refugees and Humanitarian Status Holders in Georgia”, which revealed several problems regarding livelihoods, housing, education and health. Economic Baseline Survey is required to better inform the Process of planning of their protection and integration/

target.comment: 7.1/Needs assessment for technical assistance to Information Consultation Centers conducted and relevant technical assistance provided to at least 2 Information Consultancy Centers in Shida Kartli municipalities 7.2.1/ Livelihood needs assessment of farmers of selected areas conducted to reveal most demanded vocations in the region. 7.2.2/ At least 50 farmers trained with quality vocational trainings in the most demanded agricultural vocations 8.1/ At least 270 farmers in Shida Kartli municipalities provided with farming (inputs and relevant advises (trainings) for further activity) 8.2/ At least 20 farms’ infrastructure upgraded 8.3/ At least 4 farmers cooperatives established and or supported comprised of target community members 9.1/ In 2014 UNHCR conducted “Participatory Assessment for Identification of Integration Needs of Refugees and Humanitarian Status Holders in Georgia”, which revealed several problems regarding livelihoods, housing, education and health. Economic Baseline Survey is required to better inform the Process of planning of their protection and integration/ Economic Baseline Survey conducted.

iati-activity.title: Skills for Agriculture-SDC
iati-activity.description: The proposed project aims to contribute to the development of a system of high quality vocational training and extension services in agriculture that will result in improved livelihoods of the rural population.
iati-activity.participating-org: SWISS AGENCY FOR DEVELOPMENT AND COOPERATION - SDC

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1.1: # of students trained, re-trained in agriculture and farmers benefited from extension services 1.2: # of institutions where environment improved 1.3: # of institutions and staff members which capacities were developed 2.1: # of professional standards revised/developed, teaching materials for teachers trainers and teachers trained 2.2: # of professions for which the VET teaching materials are developed, students and teachers trained 3.1: # of reforms in supported in VET in agriculture, assessments and cooperation mechanism between MoES and MoA. 3.2: private and public stakeholders are involved in provision of VET and extension services 3.3: Institutionalized format of national coordination and cooperation between the private and public sector in VET in agriculture and extension operational

baseline.comment: 1.1: Lack of accessibility of flexible Vocational Education and Training (VET) in agriculture and extension services. 1.2: Underdeveloped learning infrastructure. 1.3: weak capacities of VET colleges and extension centres to deliver teaching and training in agriculture and agricultural extension 2.1: The system of continuous VET teachers’ skills development and extension workers does not exist Indicator: # of professional standards revised/developed, teaching materials for teachers trainers and teachers trained 2.2: The system of VET for agricultural sector service providers is underdeveloped 3.1: There is the need for new policy on development of VET in agriculture and Extension services 3.3: Lack of engagement of private and public stakeholders in provision of VET in agriculture and extension 3.3: Lack of cooperation between private and public sector and nationally accessible

target.comment: 1.1. 7 specialized farmers trained in each partner college; 1,200 farmers benefit from trainings in agriculture; 3,500 farmers benefit from extension services1 model of VET officially endorsed 1.2. Infrastructure in 3 colleges & 7 extension centers developed 1.3. 4 colleges & 4 Extension centers have developed plans & strategies; 2 college staff trained 2.2. 2 VET colleges offer courses in agriculture; 15 students/college/year engaged; 20 retrained teachers; 3.2 Umbrella organization responsible for farmers education is operational 3.3 National platform for coordination of VET and Extension in Agriculture is operational

iati-activity.title: Skills for Employment-phase2
iati-activity.description: The overall objective of this phase (2014-2015) is to contribute to incorporating/formalising the VET re-training system into the formal VET system as an additional impetus for improving employability of the labour force.

Money is disbursed directly to the implementing institution and managed through a separate bank account
Money is disbursed directly to the implementing institution and managed through a separate bank account

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1/ The Concept for incorporating vocational retraining into a formal Vocational Education and Training (VET) system and tested in selected two colleges. 2/ Conceptual vision for application of software and other teaching methodologies in VET and its piloting in selected two colleges 3/ A conceptual vision and plan is developed for application of internal QI systems and their testing in selected colleges 4/ The methodology for employment programmes design and national institutional set-up design for their implementation is available

baseline.comment: 1/ No concept exist for incorporating vocational retraining into a formal Vocational and Education Training (VET) system 2/ No vision and feasible plan for application of soft and other digital teaching technologies in VET 3/ No conceptual vision and feasible plan for improving under-developed internal quality management system in VET colleges 4/ No Employment Supporting Programmes design methodology and national institutional set-up for implementing demand driven employment supporting programmes exist

target.comment: 1/ Piloting of vocational retraining schemes in selected two colleges (for at least 100 beneficiaries, of which at least 10% women). 2/ Testing and piloting new software application in two selected colleges. 3/ The conceptual vision and plan for application of internal Quality Management (QM) systems is developed and QM systems application is supported in selected two colleges. 4/ Newly developed programmes are piloted and their impact is assessed in selected colleges (for at least 110 beneficiaries, of which at least 10% women).

actual.comment: 1/ Vocational retraining schemes are being piloted in two colleges (Iberia - Kuutaisi and Phazisi - Poti). Nearly 50 students applied out of which 8% is women 2/ Trainings of teachers are undergoing for application of the new software in colleges. 3/ The internal Quality Management (QM) systems application recommendations are developed. QM systems are applied in two colleges (Iberia and Phazisi). 4/ Newly developed Vocational Training programs linked to employment scheme is undergoing (for 50 students out of which 8% women). The impact assessment will be performed in the IV Q of 2015

iati-activity.title: Sustainable Pastures Management
iati-activity.description: Sustainable Management of Pastures in Georgia to Demonstrate Climate Change Mitigation and Adaptation Benefits and Dividends for Local Communities

iati-activity.title: Sustainable Pastures Managemen
iati-activity.description: Rehabilitate 4,064 ha of degraded pastures in Vashlovani Protected Areas, introduce methods for migratory route rehabilitation applied in a 300 ha area and introduce/implement sustainable pasture management practices in the Dedoplistskaro region.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1) Sustainable pasture management plan developed and implemented 2) 300 ha migratory routes rehabilitated; 3) Local farmers knowledge in sustainable land management practices increased and SLM practices applied. 4) Pilot projects established and lessons learned extracted and disseminated. 5) Capacity of Association of sheep-breeders is improved to coordinate the activities. 6) Carbon release and sequestration monitoring established and conducted. 7) Inter-ministerial policy debate on pastures management issues initiated on national level. Key priority actions agreed. 8) Rehabilitation of 4 064 ha of degraded land. 9) Introduction of sustainable land use practices. 10) Monitoring system on climate conditions introduced 11) Introduction of new technologies. 12) Increase in productivity in piloted areas.

baseline.comment: Degraded pastures in Vashlovani Protected Areas (VPAs) 4064 ha of VPAs severely or modestly degraded4064 ha of VPAs severely or modestly degraded Local community resilience in pasturelands is low

result.title: Objective
result.description: To enhance the management effectiveness , biogeographically coverage and connectivity of Protected Areas to conserve forest ecosystems in the Achara Region

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Protected Area Coverage within the Achara Region increased

actual.comment: Target achieved. Following the official gazetting of the Machakhela National Park (29/05/2012; Reg. code: 360060000.05.001.016742), the PA coverage within the Achara region has increased by 8,733 ha and currently makes 39,202 ha total (Source: WWF, Ministry of Environment of Georgia, National Environment Agency, Forest Agency). Official demarcation of PA boundaries in progress.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Increased national and Achara PA Coverage of the Colchic Temperate Rain Forest by at least 1% and 5% respectively

baseline.comment:
Nationally: 10.7%
Achara: 15%

target.comment:
Nationally: 11.7%
Achara: 20%

actual.comment: Target achieved. With the official gazetting of Machakhela National Park (29/05/2012; Reg. code: 360060000.05.001.016742), the national and Achara PA Coverage of the Colchic Temperate Rain Forest has increased by at least 1% and 5% respectively (Source:WWF, Ministry of Environment of Georgia, National Environment Agency, Forest Agency)

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Capacity development indicator score for protected area system

baseline.comment:
Systemic: 14%
Institutional: 21%
Individual: 9%

target.comment:
Systemic: 20%
Institutional: 29%
Individual: 13%

actual.comment: Not measured during the reporting period, will be defined during the project mid-term review in 2016

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Management effectiveness for Kintrishi PA Complex, Mtirala NP and Machakhela NP measured by METT scorecard

baseline.comment:
Mtirala NP METT score:68%
Kintrishi State Reserve METT score: 62%
Kintrishi Protected Landscape METT score: 58%
Machakhela NP METT score: 11%

target.comment:
Mtirala NP METT score: 73%
Kintrishi State Reserve METT score: 67%
Kintrishi Protected Landscape METT score: 63%
Machakhela NP METT score:71%

actual.comment: Not measured during the reporting period, will be defined during the project mid-term review in 2016

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Enhanced PA Management Effectiveness in the Achara Region

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: No net increase in the illegal harvesting of wood and non wood forest products

baseline.comment:
Mtirala NP: 7.82 m3.
Kintrishi PA Complex: 0 m3.

target.comment:
Mtirala NP: < 7.82 m3.
Kintrishi PA Complex: 0 m3.

actual.comment: Not measured during the reporting period; will be defined for the project's midterm review in 2016

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description:
Reduction or no increase in illegal activity measured by % of patrols resulting in arrests or fines [1]
[1] This measures records of illegal activity incidents as a proportion of patrol effort

baseline.comment:
Mtirala NP: 1.3% (12 incidents, 915 patrols)
Kintrishi PA Complex: 0.37% (1 incident, 267 patrols)

target.comment:
Mtirala NP: 1.3% or less
Kintrishi PA Complex: 0.37% or less

actual.comment: Not measured for the reporting period. Will be measured for the next reporting period

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: PA System Expanded to increase functional connectivity of PAs in the West Lesser Caucasus

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Extent (ha) of area surveyed, and formally proclaimed and managed as Machakhela National Park (IUCN Cat II)

baseline.comment: 0 ha

target.comment: Machakhela National Park covering 8,733 ha by yr 2

actual.comment: PA official gazettement completed - The Government of Georgia undertook efforts at the project development stage to legally establish the Machakhela NP. This was agreed by Parliament in April 2012. Detailed boundary demarcation is currently in progress with the support of the project. NP Administration has been established and equipped by the Agency of Protected Areas of Georgia . Project has supported initial training of NP Administration staff, awareness raising within local communities, and establishment of the NP administration, local authorities and project coordination group, as well as refurbishment of NP temporary office within the Machakhela valley.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Distance between the Mtirala/Kintrishi PA Complex and the nearest Forest Habitat PA

baseline.comment: 13 km to Jamili PA, Turkey

target.comment: Less than 6 km to Machakhela NP

actual.comment: After the transfer of land/forest to the Machakhela National Park administration from the Forestry Agency of Achara Autonomous Republic in Autumn 2014, the territory is being managed as the protected area and thus the distance between the Mtirala/Kintrishi PA complex and the nearest forest habitat PA (i.e. Machakhela NP) is less than 6km. The national boundary of Georgia and Turkey forms the southern boundary of the Machakhela NP. The Jamilil Biosphere Reserve lies also along the border and thus the 3rd zone (Transition zone) is contiguous with Machakhela NP. The Machakhela National Park admisnitration has accepted the legal ownership/management of the for

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Necessary infrastructure investment is made by APA and Achara authorities to establish effective management of the NP

baseline.comment: Zero

target.comment: Approx. 120,000 USD

actual.comment: Both the Agency for Protected Areas and the local municipality have already committed significant resources to the establishment of the NP. This includes baseline inputs such as staff, basic as well as additional equipment (additional used vehicle from APA) and, as agreed during PPG stage, the refurbishment of 4km of the Machakhela valley road by the municipality has been completed during 2014-2015 (project cost around 404,000 US$).

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Machakhela NP boundaries and zonation decided and participatory management plan in existence

baseline.comment: Boundaries only provisionally demarcated and zonation not carried out

target.comment:
Clearly defined and consensually agreed boundaries and zones by yr 2
Consensually agreed Management plan exists by yr 3

actual.comment: The project is well on track to meet the target, expected date September 2015: A contract to undertake the detailed demarcation and land classification of the NP was selected in April 2015 by the project in agreement with APA. The PA boundary demarcation is ongoing including the collection and inputting all existing cartographic, land and field surveys data into GIS. The contractor closely liaises and informs local government and communities on the progress during implementation of this task. This activity is expected to be completed in September 2015. Additionally, a contractor has been selected to undertake a detailed resource inventory of the NP and surrounding area (baseline studies of biodiversity, traditional use, cultural heritage, etc.), which will form the baseline for monitoring, development of a zoning plan as well as the initial NP management plan (scheduled for 2016). The contractor should start its work in August 2015 and complete by February 2016.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Level of involvement of communities in the management and governance of the NP

baseline.comment: N/A

target.comment: Public-Civil Society-Community PA Planning and Management Governance Board established with proper representation and involvement of local communities in the planning and management of the Machakhela NP (by year 2)

actual.comment: The Project Coordination Group established and operating that includes local government and community representatives. The primary role of this group is to ensure coordination and information sharing during the next 2 years of intense activities to establish the functional capacity of the NP (i.e boundary and zoning, NP Administration training, infrastructure and equipment, management plan development, etc). Its secondary important role includes the creation of a mechanism by which the NP and local stakeholders can constructively interact. A study of existing and potential mechanisms for maximising practical and meaningful interaction and collaboration between communities living within the borderline of the NP (or "support zone") and the protected area is to be commissioned in the 2nd half of 2015. The study will guide the project on most viable and feasible structures and mechanisms for ensuring community engagement and role in NP management that will be incorporated into the management planning process in 2016.

iati-activity.title: Georgia's First Biennial Update Report
iati-activity.description: Assistance to Georgia in preparation of its first Biennial Update Report (BUR) for the fulfillment of the obligations under the UNFCCC

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: Biennial Update Report (BUR) completed and submitted to UNFCCC (Y/N). GHG emissions inventory report for 2010-2011 is updated and for 2012-2013 is completed.

baseline.comment: Georgia pledged to submit its first Biennial Update Report (BUR) to the UNFCCC by 2016; National Circumstance Chapter of SNC covers situation until 2012; Georgia’s GHG inventory submitted to the UNFCCC covers years until 2012; Mitigation strategy is currently being prepared under the TNC; UNEP TNA was completed in September 2012. Georgia’s First Biennial Update Report will build on the findings and recommendations of Third National Communication, as well as the outcomes of the ongoing complementary projects in the country, and will be submitted to the UNFCCC in 2016.

iati-activity.title: Tbilisi Floods-Post Disaster needs assessment
iati-activity.description: Tbilisi Floods-Post-Disaster needs assessment and risk-informed recovery

iati-activity.title: Tbilisi Floods-Post Disaster n
iati-activity.description: Tbilisi was hit by a major flash flood that wrought significant damage and caused loss of life through a large swath in the middle of the city. It was decided to assist the GoG in rapid post-disaster needs assessment for short and medium term recovery.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. Recovery needs assessment report produced 2. Recovery framework developed

baseline.comment: Insufficient government capacities to conduct long-term recovery needs assessment and develop recovery framework Lack and/or insufficient hazard data for Tbilisi Lack of updated hydrological and geological hazard risk mapping of the city Limitations in coordination between donor community and the Government on implementation of the short-to medium term recovery efforts; inaccurate/ limited information of various datasets, cases of duplication of efforts; Government request to assist with the coordination

target.comment: 1. Post-disaster Recovery needs assessment conducted 2. Recovery framework and plans developed
